Award.AwardTitle: The Early Universe as a Window to Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent observations have been able to detect remnants of physical processes that occurred a tiny fraction of second after the so-called big bang. On the theoretical side our understanding of the cosmic evolution although quite sophisticated is still incomplete. A deep understanding of how to make Einstein's theory of gravity and quantum mechanics consistent is needed to describe the very early universe, and such a theory is not fully developed yet. This project seeks to contribute to filling this gap by incorporating ideas and techniques of quantum gravity to cosmology with the goal of overcoming limitations of current models. The objective of this project is therefore twofold: to extend our understanding of the origin and fate of the universe, and to confront new quantum-gravity ideas with the last generation of observations.

The proposed research aims at developing approximate methods to incorporate quantum gravity physics in models of the early universe. Investigations will focus on theoretical as well as phenomenological aspects of quantum cosmology, with special emphasis on techniques coming from loop quantum gravity. From the theoretical point of view, it will be explored how matter fields propagate on regimes in which the quantum aspects of gravity are important, and the way in which the familiar quantum field theory in curved space-times emerges from the more fundamental theory. From the phenomenological viewpoint, the resulting theoretical framework will be applied to extend cosmological models to include Planck scale physics. Investigations will cover scalar perturbations that are responsible for the temperature anisotropies in the cosmic microwave background and galaxy distribution, non-Gaussianity, primordial magnetic fields, and particular attention will be paid to gravitational waves generated in the early universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results of this project can be divided in three groups:

 

(1)   Results in cosmology of the very early universe

One of the most important outcomes of this project has been to contribute to our understanding of the very early universe. More precisely, this project has focused on a theoretical paradigm for the early universe called loop quantum cosmology. This is a theory of quantum cosmology, and it is based on the principles underlying loop quantum gravity. The hallmark of this theory is the prediction that the universe did not begin with a big “explosion”. Rather, the Big Bang singularity of general relativity is replaced by a “bounce”. This is an instant of time at which the universe changes its evolution from a contracting to an expanding phase. This project has investigated the way loop quantum cosmology can be used to extend the most accepted model of the early universe, the inflationary scenario. This scenario suffers from well-known limitations, arising from the fact that it is based on general relativity, and hence it cannot be trusted when energy density and curvature of the universe approaches very high values. We have shown how most of these limitations are resolved within loop quantum cosmology. In the final picture, the inflationary phase of the universe is preceded by a cosmic bounce, from which inflation arises in a natural way. In this scenario one can compute the initial conditions of inflation, rather than postulate them.  These aspects have been studied in great detail, with a level of rigor and sophistication beyond what is common in early universe cosmology. The final picture is a robust candidate for the early universe, in which the assumptions and limitations underlying the theoretical developments are clear. More important, the new ideas have concrete predictions, which can be tested or falsified in the near future. Indeed, the spirit of this project is rooted in the conviction that theoretical advances in cosmology should be guided by observations. 

 

(2) Results for the theory of quantum fields in curved spacetimes

This project has contributed to extend our knowledge on physical and mathematical aspects of the theory of quantum fields propagating on a classical gravitational background. This is theory is a fundamental tool in particle physics and cosmology.

More precisely, this project has contributed: (i) to clarify mathematical questions that have been under debate for several years, related to the time evolution in this theory; (ii) to propose a new notion of vacuum in cosmology; (iii) to discover new properties of the propagation of light in the presence of gravity. More precisely, it has been found that that a fundamental symmetry that was thought to exist for the electromagnetic field in the absence of sources—the so-called electric-magnetic duality rotations--cannot exist as a result of the interaction between the electromagnetic field and gravity. This discovered has received international awards, and has important physical consequences that have opened new research avenues.

 

(3)    Broader Impacts

This project has contributed to the training of young researchers, involving several undergraduate and graduate students, including female and under-represented minorities students. The research project has also enriched the education curriculum of Louisiana State University via the creation of new courses related to the research activities. Furthermore, talks and outreach activities addressed to the general public, and to K-12 students from high diversity schools in Louisiana have been carried out in parallel with the research work.
